Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: An Efficient Framework for Design and Modeling of Complex Computer Experiments
Award.AbstractNarration:
The primary objective of this research is to develop an efficient framework for design and modeling of complex computer experiments, especially those with diverse and high-dimensional inputs and massive outputs. Computer experiments, i.e., experiments using simulation or numerical codes, have been widely used as alternatives to physical experiments, especially for studying complex phenomena. The investigator introduces new classes of designs that can efficiently accommodate large numbers of both quantitative and qualitative factors in computer experiments. The investigator also proposes a new adaptive design that is flexible and robust, yet takes into account uncertainties in the complex systems. Apart from experimental design, a novel sampling/modeling technique is proposed to reduce computational complexity and quantify model uncertainty in the analysis of computer experiments with massive data.

The proposed approaches are readily applicable to a variety of scientific disciplines and will have immediate impact on accelerating discoveries in numerous fields involving complex experiments like biomechanical engineering, systems biology, and environmental science. In particular, the proposed modeling techniques can dramatically enhance the efficiency and prediction accuracy in the analysis of cell adhesion, which plays an important role in tumor metastasis in cancer research. Moreover, the proposed methods can benefit the analysis of massive data for climate change, response to natural disasters, and the spread of pandemic disease. Integrated into the research outlined in this proposal is an education plan that emphasizes interdisciplinary training for a broad body of students and increasing participation from underrepresented groups. Results of the proposed research will be integrated into the Research Experience for Undergraduates program offered by Rutgers. Female and undergraduate students from underrepresented groups will be recruited and actively involved in the PI's research through Rutgers's highly successful Research in Science and Engineering program. Software will be written, which allows graduate and undergraduate students to have hands-on experience to implement the new methods on real examples.

Institution.Name: Rutgers University New Brunswick
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW JERSEY

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit:

Computer experiments, i.e., experiments using simulation or numerical codes, have been widely used as alternatives to physical experiments, especially for studying complex phenomena. The project focuses on the design and analysis of computer experiments. The project outcomes consist of three parts. The first part is a new class of design strategy which can improve the efficiency and robustness of design for complex computer experiments, including those with irregular experimental regions and involving both quantitative and qualitative variables. The proposed designs can lead to major advances in design of complex computer experiments. The second part is a new model for the analysis of computer experiments with complex outputs, especially binary time series which are of interest in many scientific studies. The third part is an efficient framework for sampling/modeling computer experiments which provides an accurate quantification of model uncertainty and reduces computation complexity dramatically. The proposed framework is readily applicable to various fields involving computer experiments with massive data.

Broader Impacts:

The proposed designs and modeling techniques are readily applicable to different scientific disciplines and will have impact on accelerating discoveries in numerous fields involving computer experiments, including systems biology, environmental science, and materials science. Furthermore, the proposed methods can benefit the analysis of massive data for climate change, response to natural disasters, and the spread of pandemic disease. R packages are developed based on the proposed method. They are publicly available and easy to be implemented by researchers from other disciplines. Female students and students from underrepresented groups are recruited and heavily involved in the PI?s research. In particular, four Ph.D. students graduated under partial support from this grant and three of them are female students.

 


Last Modified: 07/24/2019
Modified by: Ying Hung
